content.body: Hixie: it's not unreachable (at least on Mac)
you can always cmd-click the selected item to deselect it
othermaciej: wow, so you can
i had no idea
thought it was obvious from the way cmd-click normally works in lists...
Does it break some notion of semantics somewhere for a document to not have a location?
that question is too abstract for me to understand it

The context is an intended-to-be-ephemeral document created by a page, with a location that is only valid until the creating page is trashed.  I think you can navigate to that url fine (by the time the document is trashed and the url becomes meaningless, the navigation action is already moving).  But what does document.location then return in the new doc?
TabAtkins: is this a doc created by document.open(), createDocument(), XHR, window.open(), navigating to a File API URL, a Stream URL, or something else?
Created by a FileWriter.
Note: This isn't defined.  We're asking what it *should* return, and if it's valid for it to have no location.
wait, FileWriter returns a Document?
you don't want to do that
just have FileWriter use the same URL generation mechanism as the File API
looks like the recent bugzilla update broke my automatic scripts, i wonder if the whatwg bug submission thing still works even
oh christ it even broke my bookmarklets
Hixie: That's already being used, but the url generated thusly is intended to be trashed/meaningless when the document that created it went away.
bbiab, tgif
So if you navigate the creating document to the url of the created document (assuming this makes sense), what's the location of the created document?
why would FileWriter return a Document if it's a writer, not a reader?
Is sitemap a valid role in html5?
JonathanNeal: is it a valid role in ARIA? if so, it's valid in HTML5
Guess not http://www.w3.org/TR/2007/WD-aria-role-20071019/#roles
Or maybe this is more accurate / recent  http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/roles#role_definitions
JonathanNeal: I believe your second link is the most accurate
JonathanNeal: is the "navigation" role (or the HTML5 <nav> element) appropriate for what you are trying to do?
It is, but I get confused every now and again when I see an HTML5 blogpost use "breadcrumbs" or "sitemap"
as a role?
yes, usually next to "navigation" on the ul.
Which is weird anyway, because nav has "navigation" inherently.
JonathanNeal: Don't think sitemap has ever been an ARIA role.
poor confused web designers out there.
JonathanNeal: "breadcrumbs" used to be in the draft: http://www.w3.org/TR/2006/WD-aria-role-20060926/
Yea ... I often try to convince folks that breadcrumbs shouldn't be a list.
Rather, a paragraph.
I think the spec has it that way.
And I saw it, thought it was odd, then thought about it, and thought it was neat.
JonathanNeal: What's your reasoning?  I do breadcrumbs as an <ol>.
JonathanNeal: seems like it is semantically a list
hi all
We had a big company meeting and it was really engaging, sorry for neglecting to reply to you guys, TabAtkins and othermaciej.
JonathanNeal: no worries, I wasn't saying anything important
I think breadcrumbs can be either.  I've pushed for them to be paragraphs because I think they can work as paragraphs too.
I can see how they would be ol, because they're part of a hierarchical structure.

That's actually the reason I had us change from
    's to

    's.
My initial understanding was tha tI didn't think of <ol> and <ul> as accurately portraying a breadcrumb in a heirarchical manner.
well
you can think of it two ways:
1) a nesting hierarchy
2) an ordered list of the user's path through the site
in a way they are logically equivalent, because a list is a degenerate tree

I might hear you describing two types of breadcrumbs, the hansel and gretel style where it targets your journey, or a branch style where you see are in relationship to the site hierchy (which is how I see it)
I like the later, as I've stated, and I felt it worked excellent with the idea and example @ http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/links.html#hierarchical-link-types
JonathanNeal: Yeah, no problem.  Actually I use the latter style of breadcrumbs, where it shows the current path from the site root, but still believe <ol> is an appropriate tag for that.
i think things are back in working order after the bugzilla upgrade
but we'll see tomorrow
Hixie: I think you pinged me last night when I was away?
yeah, was going to ask you if you were aware of the plans for killing DOM Views, and if so, if you had plans for dealing with it in UIEvent
i ended up just going with changing viewArg to dummyArg in the drag and drop event stuff, but i'll change it to whatever you end up deciding on
gotta go right now though
should be online tomorrow
Hixie: ok, let's talk tomorrow
k
whos up!
JonathanNeal: i accept patches (re http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20100402#l-471 )
reading
zcorpan, you're simon's html5 elements page?
yes
Then I will get to work immediately.
cool :)
Is there an even more multipage version of the html spec?
I want to make sure I'm not reinventing the wheel unnecessarily.
there's an index in the multipage spec
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/section-index.html#index
i guess the table of contents also has all the elements listed
the toc is in the right order
i guess html5-elements' order is out of date
I just noticed that the html5 spec is written in the us language of hixie
it would be nice if i could generate html5-elements with a script that scrapes the spec
Well, it should be pretty easy with ajax.
It just means we'll need to host a local coy and fetch it via ajax.
Or curl it to proxy ajax.
generating it with javascript fails on the same-origin policy
could write a bookmarklet
actually a bookmarklet would not be a bad idea. would be easy to just appendChild()ing the right elements and getting innerHTML when you're done
the elements from the toc, and the attributes of each element from the index (loaded in an iframe)
zcorpan, i don't get, how does the bookmarklet work?
It runs locally so how can it get the content?
you run it when having the html5 spec loaded
oh ...
Maybe it would be better if I just copied the parts I wanted from the spec into separate files :P
adds wbr and device to html5-elements
wonders what a graph of number of songs owned per artist against number of plays per artist would look like
expects for him it'd be a line through the origin, more or less
zcorpan, can't you just prefix the current links with http://www.whatwg.org/html
zcorpan, the automatic redirects should take care of the rest
Goodmorning!
certainly feels like morning
shouldn't the spec explain how <wbr> is different from zero width whitespace?
is it right to say that there is no stable release of a browser with HTML5 parser?
fx 3.6 has one, but disabled
by default
lazni: true, but was wondering if there were anything else I did not know about.
Six different types of "conforming", I guess it'll be easy to adhere to at least one of them
I think I am losing my mind
Present tense?
What happened to the bit of the websockects protocol spec where it talks about constructing the random tokens?
Philip`: Add the word "further" if that helps
Whoa, Shelley is riding the deletionist wave like a pro...
Why does WAHTWG not publish a version of websockts in a sane format (i.e. HTML)
and without a multitude of different versions
Eating broccoli sure is fun :D
jgraham: complete.html has the websockets protocol in it
wants a tiling window manager that actually behaves as he wants one to :P
gsnedders: ion?
gsnedders: Write your own
Philip`: That's my general feeling
Gah.
based on xmonad
That means learning HAskell
*Haskell
That makes it a doubly good option
Hixie: Yeah I realised that eventually
We could do with a multipage complete.html though
likes multipage when he knows exactly what he is looking for and the section is relatively self contained
gsnedders: Define "as you want one to"
tried xmonad for a while but found that it was very inconvenient when you wanted some unusual layout
(so prefers the relatively simple solution of using compiz+the grid plugin)
(but would like it if the grid plugin had more tiling-window-manager like features)
jgraham: i'd be up for that if someone sets up the multipage splitter in such a way that i can use it from the script
is somewhat scared that he can go into an IRC channel he's never been in before, and have said to him from someone he's never heard of, "Hey Geoffrey! Nice to see you here!"
i know the feeling
I mean, since when was I that well known on the intartubes?
i usually reply "um, hi"
Yeah, my normal response too
Obviously your influence is wearing off on me :P
Philip`: Can you do whatever needs to be done with the multipage splitter?
<meta http-equiv="text/html" value="text/html;charset=utf-8"> works if I'm testing this correctly
